revisions:
[{'created': '2017-02-06 14:09:16.000000000', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: Icd8635f99bb76b38668c631be74fdeb70e59e440
'}]
commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: Icd8635f99bb76b38668c631be74fdeb70e59e440

[{'created': '2017-06-08 07:25:46.000000000', 'message': 'Remove support for py34.

The gating on python 3.4 is restricted to <= Mitaka. This is due to
the change from Ubuntu Trusty to Xenial, where only python3.5 is
available. There is no need to continue to keep these settings.

Change-Id: Iab562c5bea2abbb84d34e9f4d1cfcc7b64b845aa
'}]
commit_message:
Remove support for py34.

The gating on python 3.4 is restricted to <= Mitaka. This is due to
the change from Ubuntu Trusty to Xenial, where only python3.5 is
available. There is no need to continue to keep these settings.

Change-Id: Iab562c5bea2abbb84d34e9f4d1cfcc7b64b845aa

commit_message:
Retire repository

Fuel (from openstack namespace) and fuel-ccp (in x namespace)
repositories are unused and ready to retire.

This change removes all content from the repository and adds the usual
README file to point out that the repository is retired following the
process from
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/011647.html

commit_message:
Add support for custom Elasticsearch config

Elasticsearch Curator will be driven by custom config. This adds
support in Kayobe for managing it.

Change-Id: Ie739ffbd67c6c26175f152449a7b7276ffa87824
Story: 2006852
Task: 37443

commit_message:
[ceph-client] remove rbd pool init step

This it to remove "rbd"  pool intilization since its not
required as appliction enable in next step does the same.

Change-Id: I07ecdbe417f0156005ebf7cef8fd9e40bace3920

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-17 07:54:50.000000000', 'message': 'Remove trusty fuel jobs

Remove jobs from fuel repos that still use trusty nodes so that we can
cleanup trusty from infrastructure.
Add noop-jobs template instead.

Note that fuel was retired from OpenStack in 2017 and none of the
repositories touched here has any change merged since December 2017.

Change-Id: I1fa7d5d38afb91f5bdd8bae0efe0ee8244cf22a8
'}, {'created': '2019-12-18 08:27:14.000000000', 'message': 'Retire fuel and fuel-ccp repositories (step 2)

Retire fuel from openstack namespace and fuel-ccp from x namespace,
these repositories are dead.

Announcement:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/011647.html

Also remove fuel-specs from specs index page.

This is step 2 in
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I1fa7d5d38afb91f5bdd8bae0efe0ee8244cf22a8

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/011647.html

Change-Id: I1fa7d5d38afb91f5bdd8bae0efe0ee8244cf22a8
"}]
commit_message:
Retire fuel and fuel-ccp repositories (step 2)

Retire fuel from openstack namespace and fuel-ccp from x namespace,
these repositories are dead.
This includes the tuning-box repo, it's part of fuel.

Announcement:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-December/011647.html

Also remove fuel-specs from specs index page.

This is step 2 in
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I1fa7d5d38afb91f5bdd8bae0efe0ee8244cf22a8

This updates the deploy-ansible-docker-support role to remove the
become and become_user configuration options from the included tasks
and instead adds them at the block level

recheck some fluke in reviewstats.tests.test_projectinfo.TestProjectInfo.test_project_definitions_load'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-11-14 02:47:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 31245, 'date': '2019-12-03 10:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-18 15:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-04 16:16:55.000000000', 'message': "reviewers: make --project and --stable mutually exclusive

When using the reviewers command to get stats on stable branch
reviews, I always think I can specify --stable and --project nova
to get nova stable reviews, but that's not how the command
works and the --project option is ignored resulting in a report
which I don't expect, i.e. there are non-nova reviewers in the
report.

This makes --project and --stable mutually exclusive to avoid that
confusion.

Change-Id: Ie9938f5e68f27b9a5a58635be2185365f041136f
"}]
commit_message:
reviewers: make --project and --stable mutually exclusive

When using the reviewers command to get stats on stable branch
reviews, I always think I can specify --stable and --project nova
to get nova stable reviews, but that's not how the command
works and the --project option is ignored resulting in a report
which I don't expect, i.e. there are non-nova reviewers in the
report.

This makes --project and --stable mutually exclusive to avoid that
confusion.

Change-Id: Ie9938f5e68f27b9a5a58635be2185365f041136f

commit_message:
Switch reviewers command to use argparse

optparse is deprecated in python 2.7 and not available
starting in python3. This changes the reviewers command
to use argparse instead.

Change-Id: I76f270b4e998e8cf2a56c12d7bf70c0651c69d16

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-17 19:19:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix monasca-grafana being unbuildable due to old npm

Affected builds on Ubuntu which had:
npm 3.5.2
while the latest was:
npm 6.13.4
And CentOS had:
npm 5.6.0

This patch runs npm update via npm.
Pinned to 6.x.

Additionally, this moves npm packages prefix (root) to
/usr/local to avoid conflicts with native packages.

Change-Id: Ibaacc1cc478b2b2f8196a5da4eea3570d7d310ff
Closes-bug: #1856699
(cherry picked from commit 308e85aa413da84ed107b27fa09a3f0e0a64392f)

commit_message:
Tune down multinode concurrency

Reduce the multinode concurrency and number
of VMs so we don't run Rackspace VMs out of
disk space.

This is an issue that was reported by the
infra team.

[0]: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ironic/%23openstack-ironic.2019-12-16.log.html#t2019-12-16T17:38:15

Change-Id: I867bac9e247605e561cc7ee4522f70ce6de368d4

[{'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-11-07 09:25:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-11-07 09:26:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Tests to be added'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-11-07 11:04:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/693323/1 : FAILURE in 1h 38m 34s'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-07 14:58:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Hello,

Some feedbacks inline:'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-11-08 08:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-08 08:59:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Your changes LGTM in the current state so +1.

My comments was more general feedbacks.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2019-11-13 11:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Is there ever a case when the admin wants to choose between stopping an particular agent gracefully or not? If there is, you may want to do this by handling two different signals. If there's not, then the config option approach seems okay."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-11-13 11:31:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Non-graceful stop is needed when admin does not want data-plane downtime due to keepalived processes exit. Non-graceful stop is possible with SIGKILL or with SIGTERM and cleanup_on_shutdown set to False.'}, {'account_id': 7249, 'date': '2019-11-15 14:39:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-11-18 07:19:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-11-18 08:59:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-11-20 09:18:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

It was discussed during last L3 meeting.

This is the meeting log:
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/neutron_l3/2019/neutron_l3.2019-11-13-14.02.log.html

This is the irc channel log:
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-meeting/%23openstack-meeting.2019-11-13.log.html#t2019-11-13T14:25:47-2

Firstly, IMO, a new config option works for me. But we have to know why we need that.
Here are some questions from the log:
14:30:05 <liuyulong> But according to the bug description, it the pod goes down, then everything is gone. (Maybe not, I'm not familiar with kubernetes...)
14:31:51 <liuyulong> Or the real story is the the l3-agent is running in container but the child processes are all in the host. Then everything remains after pod down.

The python l3-agent process is in the container, then there are other processes spawned by the agent for HA routers or other resources, where are these processes running? They are still runnning directly on the physcal host? If so, then this config is worthy for such case.


And then, this also should be approved by neutron drivers meeting."}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-11-20 10:16:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/693323/3 : SUCCESS in 2h 02m 44s'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-12-04 07:12:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

>>14:30:05 <liuyulong> But according to the bug description, it the pod goes down, then everything is gone. (Maybe not, I'm not familiar with kubernetes...)
>>14:31:51 <liuyulong> Or the real story is the the l3-agent is running in container but the child processes are all in the host. Then everything remains after pod down.

>>The python l3-agent process is in the container, then there are other processes 
>>spawned by the agent for HA routers or other resources, where are these 
>>processes running? They are still runnning directly on the physcal host? If so, 
>>then this config is worthy for such case.

What's left on the host after pod is down is router namespaces with corresponding devices, which were not cleaned up because keepalived was killed in non-graceful way by kubernetes. So this patch makes l3 agent do graceful keepalived shutdown so it cleans namespaces and devices."}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2019-12-04 07:12:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

subject: Removed unused variable pools
messages:
[{'account_id': 25591, 'date': '2019-10-29 16:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20191, 'date': '2019-10-31 08:14:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-04 16:14:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Hello,

Thanks for these changes.

First, I don't think we can consider this as a bug (cf. https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1850470), you don't speak about related issue or things like that. I put a -1 there related to this, see my comment inline, else these changes seems ok.

As you saied this variable was added by https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/53b9d741a8f5a2fa6cbaea9e23a3679a6af235a4

The same variable existed also on the qpid driver but this driver was deleted:
 
https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/commit/53b9d741a8f5a2fa6cbaea9e23a3679a6af235a4/oslo/messaging/_drivers/impl_qpid.py#L453

Initialy this variable made sense:

https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/commit/53b9d741a8f5a2fa6cbaea9e23a3679a6af235a4/oslo/messaging/_drivers/amqp.py#L95

but now the mechanismes under the hood seems to have evolued and the connection pools seems managed through the `connection_cls` by:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/044e6f20e65084f3c4ecc554672d3271b2a2acd3/oslo_messaging/_drivers/pool.py#L127

For all these reasons I think we can remove this variable."}, {'account_id': 25591, 'date': '2019-11-18 13:46:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Hello,
 > 
 > Thanks for these changes.
 > 
 > First, I don't think we can consider this as a bug (cf.
 > https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1850470), you don't
 > speak about related issue or things like that. I put a -1 there
 > related to this, see my comment inline, else these changes seems
 > ok.
 > 
 > As you saied this variable was added by https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/53b9d741a8f5a2fa6cbaea9e23a3679a6af235a4
 > 
 > The same variable existed also on the qpid driver but this driver
 > was deleted:
 > 
 > https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/commit/53b9d741a8f5a2fa6cbaea9e23a3679a6af235a4/oslo/messaging/_drivers/impl_qpid.py#L453
 > 
 > Initialy this variable made sense:
 > 
 > https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/commit/53b9d741a8f5a2fa6cbaea9e23a3679a6af235a4/oslo/messaging/_drivers/amqp.py#L95
 > 
 > but now the mechanismes under the hood seems to have evolued and
 > the connection pools seems managed through the `connection_cls` by:
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/044e6f20e65084f3c4ecc554672d3271b2a2acd3/oslo_messaging/_drivers/pool.py#L127
 > 
 > For all these reasons I think we can remove this variable.

Hi Herve,

thanks for the review. Sorry for my late reply. I was at OpenInfra Summit 2 weeks ago.

Basically I didn't face any problem with this unused variable. When I read the code, I found this variable with running 'vulture' tool by accident. 

This variable is a Class Variable. So normally it doesn't have any negative effects even when it's not used. However to locate an unused Class Variable is not so easy.

Do you want to remove the 'Closes-Bug' link from the commit? I don't have problem to do so."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:06:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 11:06:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Agreed, this isn't a bug. Have removed the bug link and closed the bug itself. Going to fast approve now since it's trivial."}]

commit_message:
Invoke correct python version in shell scripts

The oslotest shell scripts were using /usr/bin/python by default, and did
take into account the $PYTHON variable, so one could choose to use
Python 3 instead of Python 2.

This patch looks if a $PYTHON variable exists. If not, then it sets it
to "python" by default, otherwise, it uses whatever exists, so it is now
possible to do PYTHON=python3 oslo_debug_helper for starting tests.

Change-Id: I6df0ac0d84fd964251a1af9e27dadb954a2ad691

commit_message:
Remove the neutron-grenade job definition

All the user of neutron-grenade from Ussuri gate
onwards has been switched to grenade-py3 job (except
neutron which is running neutron-grenade-multinode).

We can remove the job definition also now and all
stable gate using this job will find the job definition
from neutron stable branches.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694234/
Change-Id: I631f0bfbe7e4ee2df89e2eca2060331796e7a0b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-16 22:17:22.000000000', 'message': 'Block ability update callback_url

A malicious user with:

* API access normally reserved for the provisioning,
  cleaning, rescue networks.
* Insight about a node, such as a MAC address, or baremetal node
  UUID.
* Insight into the state of the node, such as the access provided
  to Compute API users, or other Bare Metal API users.

Can submit an erroneous ``heartbeat`` to the ironic-api endpoint
with a ``callback_url`` that is not of the actual intended agent.
This can potentially cause a rescue, cleaning, or deployment
operation to be derailed, or at worst commands to be sent to
to an endpoint the malicious user controls.

Story: 2006773
Task: 37295
Change-Id: I1a5e3c2b34d45c06fb74e82d0f30735ce9041914
(cherry picked from commit 931c12598296dad676b2d64b66fef6e95ad3939b)
'}]
commit_message:
Block ability update callback_url

A malicious user with:

* API access normally reserved for the provisioning,
  cleaning, rescue networks.
* Insight about a node, such as a MAC address, or baremetal node
  UUID.
* Insight into the state of the node, such as the access provided
  to Compute API users, or other Bare Metal API users.

Can submit an erroneous ``heartbeat`` to the ironic-api endpoint
with a ``callback_url`` that is not of the actual intended agent.
This can potentially cause a rescue, cleaning, or deployment
operation to be derailed, or at worst commands to be sent to
to an endpoint the malicious user controls.

Story: 2006773
Task: 37295
Change-Id: I1a5e3c2b34d45c06fb74e82d0f30735ce9041914
(cherry picked from commit 931c12598296dad676b2d64b66fef6e95ad3939b)

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-17 08:43:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-17 08:43:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-23 10:50:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-23 10:52:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

A bit more rework and cleaning in this patch. Good to be reviewed :)'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-23 13:20:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-23 18:18:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I won't block this addition, but I am mildly concerned by any features which encourage continued use of the Sem-Ver: pseudo headers since there's no good way to "undo" them if you realize you merged a change which came with too greedy of a SemVer bump (non-fast-forwardable Git surgery aside).'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-23 20:54:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Ho, that's interesting. I am actively promoting "semantic commit" in our company, for packages that has a linear history it is perfect. I still have to hack around pbr that does a very good job as backbone of these packages (they look like this opensource one: https://github.com/gsemet/cfgtree).

When I want to force a jump of version for whatever reason, I can still push manually a tag so for my packages, PBR semver is just a way to automatize the versioning. I simply does 'make tag-pbr" and the right tag is pushed to our git repository and the pypi packages is automatically built. So here I simply contribute back to pbr in hope it helps others using pbr.

Semanit Commit seems marveillous, and also allows to "teach" external contributors about what is semver and how a "contract" between the library and its users works, how to declare evolution, what is an api-break etc.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-06-26 18:09:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I think Jeremy's concern is that if you accidentally commit a feature patch with a Sem-Ver: api-break tag instead of Sem-Ver: feature then there's no way to undo that.  You can't go back and change the commit message once it's been pushed to a public git repo.

It's a valid concern.  One hacky(?) option would be to have a way to decrement verions with Sem-Ver headers.  In the above case, maybe you push a commit that has a "Sem-Ver: undo api-break" tag that decrements the major version.  It would open up the possibility of bad versions being created if the incorrect patch was already released, but that could happen with manual versioning too.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-26 20:00:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Hi. I do not really see your point. Mistakes happen much often when the versioning is made by human, and even if some entered a bad sem-ver in a commit message, if the generated tag does not look good to you, you can always 'git tag --force' the version you want.

This commit does not change this behavior, simply makes it easier to us sem-ver. I am not in position of recommending it or not, outside our organisation, but so far for the few internal modules we maintain, we find it game changing. Developers and even maintainers did mistakes all the time, simply because there were no easy way for a contributor to communicate the level of impact it changes has. sem-ver is a way to communicate this, if other thinks it is not a good idea to use it, they are free to not use it."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-26 21:20:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

It mostly comes up in the context of published snapshot sdists/wheels or source installs of not-yet-released repository state. Once you course-correct with an accurate tag, the version number rolls backwards and you need to "downgrade" to the release.

As I said, I find sem-ver footers a problematic feature and so am not keen on new work which solidifies its use (vs deprecating), but I'm not going to block this if other reviewers are in favor.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-06-26 22:05:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Do the open stack community/ core team use sem-ver internally? I see lot of packages on the npm world that use similar tags and it is pretty great.
Do you feel it will be deprecated soon ?

I also agree that playing with prerelease is too tricky. I usually do not recommend to use it in prod at all, if so, it is up to the one who decided to use it to fix its env.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-06-27 17:09:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I don't think we use it in general.  Our release process is documented in https://github.com/openstack/releases and it involves manually specifying whether a release is bugfix, feature, or major.

Maybe we should have a broader discussion about this?  It seems bad to leave the feature in a supported-but-not-recommended limbo."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-27 17:21:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

The only reason I knew it was in there is some projects have accidentally merged changes with Sem-Ver commit message footers not knowing they had a magic effect on dev versioning, and so were stuck with it for snapshots and local development installs until the next tag.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-02 15:23:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

(6 comments)

> The only reason I knew it was in there is some projects have
 > accidentally merged changes with Sem-Ver commit message footers not
 > knowing they had a magic effect on dev versioning, and so were
 > stuck with it for snapshots and local development installs until
 > the next tag.

I also don't like the aspect of the footers feature that forces the computed dev version to update. I don't mind keeping the footers for computing a version in a passive way, like with the new release_version command added here or even in a new tag command. That feels like a convenience, rather than the imposition that we have now.

So maybe we could deprecate the automatic use of the footers, but retain the logic for computing the new version so that these commands can use it?

More comments inline."}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-02 20:53:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-02 21:00:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(5 comments)

> I also don't like the aspect of the footers feature that forces the computed dev version to update. I don't mind keeping the footers for computing a version in a passive way, like with the new release_version command added here or even in a new tag command. That feels like a convenience, rather than the imposition that we have now.
> 
> So maybe we could deprecate the automatic use of the footers, but retain the logic for computing the new version so that these commands can use it?

Thanks for the review.

About the issue about dev-version computation, what if dev version kind of force changes to the level of "bugfix", so that in case of footer mistakes (or revert, ...), package maintainer would still have the full latitude to fix with the right version tag.

This would require to distinguish between the event "compute a version for dev-version", in which case, force to "bugfix.
And "compute a version for any other case" (release, rc, alpha/beta, ...), in which case use the current algorithm.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-02 21:07:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-02 21:54:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-02 22:35:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-03 08:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-03 08:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-03 11:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-03 11:00:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-03 12:55:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-03 12:56:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

I left more detailed comments on PS11. The -1 is for going beyond a command to show the proposed tag version, which I think extends pbr too far into territory already well covered by git-tag.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 21:26:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

i agree. I rework it asap'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 21:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 21:53:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 21:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review+1

done :)'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 21:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18: Patch Set 17 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 21:57:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 22:22:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

Doug, Jeremy,

Can you look at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/580231/ to see if it what you meant to deal with the dev version issue?'}, {'account_id': 27201, 'date': '2018-07-04 22:37:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-09-18 16:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

A few concerns inline. Seems like this is headed in the right direction though.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-18 15:08:30.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This seems to have stalled, so I'm going to close it out to indicate as such. Please ping me on IRC if you (or anyone) wants to pick it back up though!"}]

commit_message:
pbr show-next-version command

Allow to display the next release version, as
calculated using sem-ver footers in commit messages.

Also available:
    python setup.py show_release_version

Change-Id: I4ba355225c7f22f1923acb7fd844deb61a1720ea
sem-ver: feature
Signed-off-by: Gaetan Semet <gaetan@xeberon.net>
